text:
CHRISTINE LIU: So we're going
to talk about whiteboards.

They are like the
office cliche, right?

You got staplers and
copiers and whiteboards.

And it's just like productivity
and brainstorming and exciting
stuff.

I think we can all
agree that whiteboards,

whether it's real or
virtual, they're helpful.
You can jot down notes.
You can sketch little things.
You can put up sticky notes.

But the more I
thought about them,

the more I had questions,
like, oh, maybe they
have this secret power.

There's a reason why
they're everywhere.
Am I missing something?
Are we all missing something?
Turns out there is more to it.

Stick around if you want to
see these tips in action.

Let's learn how to
really use a whiteboard.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

Before we start, a brief
word from our sponsor.
We all want better ways to work.

Confluence, the leading
team collaboration software,

keeps your whole
company in sync.

Confluence is one place where
you can create, collaborate,

and share work so you can
spend less time meeting
and more time doing.

Get it free today at
Atlassian.com/meet-less.
JAKE KNAPP: Finally.

Finally, somebody wants
to talk about whiteboards.
About time.

CHRISTINE LIU:
That's Jake Knapp.

He invented the
Design Sprint and he's
written Sprint and Make Time.

As a designer, he's thought a
lot about tools and processes--
tools like whiteboards.

In your book Sprint, you write
that whiteboards make you
smarter.
Can you unpack that?

JAKE KNAPP: The whiteboard
is extra memory for us.

And it means that we don't
have to just hold in our head

what the person said in
the last sentence or two.

And we don't have to constantly
try to convince our colleagues

or try to talk each other down
or try to construct-- oh, God,
what's--

we don't have to
necessarily be quite so

subject to recency bias
and all these things.
We can see.

We can put things up there
and extend our memory.

And in that way, it does
absolutely make us smarter.

CHRISTINE LIU: Jake is a
big, big fan of whiteboards.

What drives you bananas
about how you see
some people use whiteboards?

JAKE KNAPP: The main thing is
when people don't use them.
That's number one.

And it's so common that the
whiteboard is either garbage,
like it's small or it's--
[CAT SCREECHING]
[INTERPOSING VOICES]

--is weird and you
can still see what

people wrote before because
it doesn't erase properly.
It's a weird material.
Or there's no whiteboard at all.
[HORROR MUSIC]

That's like saying, well,
we're going to write software
and we don't have computers.
It's just-- it's insane.

CHRISTINE LIU: There's
a blank canvas,

and you can do
whatever you want.

But I think that freedom is
a little anxiety-inducing.
Am I doing this right?

Am I putting stuff
in the right places?
I need help.

I'm looking at this
blank white screen,

and I'm just trying
to figure out

what's the best way to
start filling it out
in a structured way.

JAKE KNAPP: Imagine
yourself at IKEA,

and you're looking
at a shelving unit.

There are all these
different components,

and you can figure out
what shelves you want
and how many do I want.

Well, the whiteboard is sort
of like that shelving unit.

And I'm going to build myself
the shelves that I need,

and then I'll have a place to
stick things when they come up
in the conversation.

I like to start off a bigger
project meeting by figuring out
what the long term goal is.

So I might be writing
"Long term goal."

Then I know that what's
in this area here--

I'm going to draw
this rectangle here,

and I want us to fill in
what the long term goal is.
This is what we're all about.
This is what grounds us.

Similarly, I could copy
this, move it down here,

and I could say, how are
we going to-- how are
we going to measure that goal?

What are-- if we go
out into the future

and we've achieved that
goal, what will it look like?

What are the things that
we could tangibly measure?

What about-- what
about the risks?

I don't want to just talk about
the things that could go well.

What are all the
potential problems?

We've got now this new
shelf for pessimism.

Another thing I
really like to do

is to make a map of
how does this work.

You might think of it as like,
how does our system work?

CHRISTINE LIU: Jake also
uses this technique which
I love called Note and Vote.

Basically, if
you're in a meeting

and people are just trying
to talk over each other or--
[CHATTER]

--here's my idea,
here's my idea--
just pause.
Put on a timer.

Everyone quietly
and independently

write down their
ideas on sticky notes.

JAKE KNAPP: And then
you use the whiteboard
to capture all of those things.

CHRISTINE LIU: At
this point, hopefully

you already have someone you've
designated as the decision
maker.

They take all of these
votes into consideration
and make the final call.
Done.
Decision made.
Move on.

Might be tempted to use
so many fancy things
on your whiteboard.
[HORROR MUSIC]
No.
Fight the urge.

You want to keep it
super simple, boring.
The ideas are not boring.
The ideas are amazing and rich.

But everything else should
be just supporting them.

JAKE KNAPP: Another thing
that drives me nuts is
multicolored sticky notes.
[HORROR MUSIC]

CHRISTINE LIU: But
they're so fun!

JAKE KNAPP: Well,
they do look fun.

Your brain starts to try to
figure out, why is this green
and why is this orange?

And you stop looking so
much at the information.

So it's adding extra
hurdles to jump over.
[WOMAN SCREAMING]
[MUSIC PLAYING]

CHRISTINE LIU: Stick to
one color of sticky note.
Jake really loves yellow.

And then, everything
else is literally just
words, boxes, and arrows.
Nothing else.
Keep it simple.

So another question
is, does it really

matter what type of
whiteboard you use?
Well, sort of.

Let's talk about
digital whiteboards.

What you're looking
for is something that's

robust and reliable
and responsive,

yet you want it
to be easy enough

to use so anyone
joining the meeting

can figure out
things pretty fast.

And if you're going old school
whiteboard, go big or go home.
[EXCITING MUSIC]

JAKE KNAPP: Like,
you really want

as much surface area as
possible if you're working
with people in real life.

Something like this sucks if
it's like shape like this,

because you can only
write a list of texts.

You can only make
a PowerPoint slide.

CHRISTINE LIU: Yeah,
Jake has opinions.
There's more.

JAKE KNAPP: Then they
should be a landscape.

I'm all about plain
yellow sticky notes.

And actually, the adhesive
on the post-it brand ones
is too strong.

Yeah, and then you
use Expo markers.

CHRISTINE LIU: We learned
how to use a whiteboard
in better ways, which is great.

But I think the
bigger takeaway here
is, why care about whiteboards?
And I think I got it.

It's because
whiteboards are the tool
to use to prevent bad meetings.

Everybody's ideas are heard,
not just the loudest people.
You have clarity.

Everyone's looking
at a shared space,

so there's less room for
miscommunication or error.

And then, wow, you
have an action plan.
You're making decisions.
It's moving along.

You are getting things
done, and I love that.

JAKE KNAPP: That core purpose
of doing better work together,
it's actually quite noble.
In a way, we're joking.
I'm joking about it.

It's geeky and it's nerdy, and
I know I'm way too into it.

But what could be
more important?

We can't do amazing
things without the help
of other people.

And we waste so much of our
time just spinning our wheels

in meetings that are pointless,
having pointless conversations.

These things are solvable,
and it's a great, simple place
to start.

CHRISTINE LIU: If you're still
watching, one, thank you.
But two, I'm really curious.
What do you want me to explore?

What problems do
you have at work?
I'd love to solve them.
Please leave a comment.
I'd love to hear your thoughts.

And if you have any other
ideas, throw them my way.
All right.
Peace out.
